Message.Title: Wild action here!
Message.Msg: Is anybody watching this?

Topic.Title: Wild action here!

Message.Msg: Wild options expiry week to the extreme! --Bernanke remarks about US bond purchase vague. WS didn't like it --China manufacturing slowing (announced yesterday); all China's trading partners tanked overnight --Options expired Friday ahead of a long weekend; traders don't want to hold positions (long or short), unwinding ahead of times --Market had been rallying, now pausing (the short correction in a secular bull market are often violent, and this looks like one of those to me). Keep a list of stocks which buck the trend and go long on those.

Message.Title: Tegra automotive backlog $2 billion
Message.Msg: Rob Csongor: "It’s actually interesting one of the things that I don’t think many people are aware off, one of the largest backlog that we have in terms of orders and the company is actually from automotive, the bad news on automotive is that it takes a long time to get a design win, but the good news is when you get a design win its sticky and it stays for quite a while. So we actually have orders going out many years into the future and actually our actual backlog right now in automotive for Tegra is $2 billion in revenue, it is really outstanding."

Message.Title: "XBox One and PS4 Could Add $9B in Revenue for AMD (AMD) - Jefferies"
Message.Msg: "XBox One and PS4 Could Add $9B in Revenue for AMD (AMD) - Jefferies" "Jefferies reiterated a Buy rating and $5 price target on AMD (NYSE: AMD) after Microsoft's (Nasdaq: MSFT) xBox One announcement confirmed their expectations that AMD's processor is driving the product. "We reiterate our Buy rating and view our estimates for AMD as conservative in light of design wins in both the PS4 and xBox One," analyst Mark Lipacis said. This follows a win in the PS4. "We believe AMD will receive revenues of $60-$80 per PS4 and xBox One shipped for its processor," he said. He continued, "We believe that both the PS3 and xBox 360 shipped between 70-to-75 million units each over the past few years. Assuming similar success, for the PS4 and xBox One, and assuming $60 ASP per processor and 20% operating margin would translate to $9 billion in revenues and $2.40 in EPS over 6 years, or an average annual EPS of $0.40." " Source: streetinsider

Message.Title: The Xbox One Makes Me Want to Buy a New Xbox 360
Message.Msg: "Immediately, my biggest fear was confirmed—the One's new x86-based CPU architecture means it won't be able to play Xbox 360 games. Over the years, my family has amassed more than 100 titles for the 360, representing many more hundreds of hours of fun but also quite a chunk of change." pcmagDOTcom/article2/0,2817,2419420,00.asp

Message.Title: JUST IN: Tom's hardware says Tegra 4i is more "future proof" than competition (meaning QC)
Message.Msg: The beauty of the update is that new hardware isn't involved. This is not a new chip. Thanks to the Tegra 4i's software defined radio technology (pdf), support for new technologies can be integrated with a mere software update instead. That makes it somewhat more future proof than competing chips, as it's now compatible with a network that doesn't even exist in the real world… yet. "An additional advantage of the technology is its tiny size. Because the modem is designed with general purpose Deep Execution Processors (DXP), it’s 40 percent the size of a conventional LTE modem," the company said. "The benefit is a fast, high performance, adaptable modem in a tiny footprint." The chip's modem is also multi-mode, the company said, delivering 4G LTE-Advanced while also supporting LTE Cat 3, 3G, and 2G, meaning it will work even where LTE networks aren’t available. Other LTE-Advanced features will be coming soon in software, the company said. Because there are no 4G LTE-Advanced networks up and running, Nvidia had an emulated version running at CTIA, and the "Phoenix" Tegra 4i reference smartphone showing speeds of 150 Mbps. Phoenix is a fully-functional smartphone with a 5-inch 1080p display, 13MP camera and integrated 4G LTE. "We also demonstrated Phoenix running on a live AT&T LTE network – showing video streaming over LTE and voice calls," the company said. "It’s a great proof point of our strong progress in Tegra 4i modem stability and performance." tomshardwareDOTcom/news/Tegra-4i-Phoenix-LTE-Advanced-CTIA-2013-i500,22703.html

Topic.Title: JUST IN: Tom's hardware says Tegra 4i is more "future proof" than competition (meaning QC)

Message.Msg: Tegra 4i in a nutshell: 1. Fast 2. Stability of performance 3. Cheap (small silicon real estate) 4. Ease of design and manufacturing by handset makers 5. Multi-mode with respect to spectrum; adjustments due to geographics can be made easy by over-the-air firmware update. No new hardwares required which are both expensive and time consuming (ie. QC's dilemma) 6. Background compatible with Cat3 LTE, 3G and 2G networks - one bird kills all stones. 6. Much more future proof - a highly welcome feature by consumers, manufacturers and carriers. What is there not to like about Tegra 4I?? (other than the facts that shorts and bashers hate it)

Message.Title: Out-of-the-Box Idea for the Day: AMD Should Buy NVDA
Message.Msg: AMD and NVDA would be an interesting combination. Of course, anyone who buys AMD would face the potential loss of the x86 license, which is pretty limiting. Hard to overstate just how limiting. Of course, AMD can make purchases. They could, if both parties chose, buy NVDA in such a lop-sided way as to provide NVDA shareholders and management the substantially controlling interest in the final company. A clever lawyer could surely figure it out. Just remember to send me my by finder's fee. Okay?

Message.Title: "Tech stocks: HP surges, AMD sinks" lol
Message.Msg: "Tech stocks: HP surges, AMD sinks" "A dip in revenue and earnings doesn't seem to be slowing Hewlett-Packard's stock price. Let's take a look at the tech stocks to watch Thursday: HP shares soar. The largest personal computer maker's stock price has surged 11% in pre-market trading after its second-quarter earnings report topped Wall Street estimates. The company pulled in $27.6 billion in the second quarter, down from more than $30 billion generated the same time a year ago. However, HP CEO Meg Whitman says her plans to turaround the ailing PC maker are still on track. "This (2013) is a fix-and-rebuild year, and we think revenue growth is possible in 2014," she says. Advanced Micro Devices down. Shares of AMD have dropped 3% after unveiling new chips aimed at tablets and thin laptops. As Cnet reports, the chips are specifically focused on low- to mid-priced gadgets." Message.Title: Hisense Tegra 3 Tablet- Sold at Walmart
Message.Msg: Nvidia still has design wins with Tegra 3 rolling out in value tablets. article below is from PC Mag: Hisense, a company known for making low-cost HDTVs, teamed up with Nvidia on Thursday to unveil a pair of Android tablets. The Sero 7 LT and Sero 7 Pro will be the company's first tablets to feature Google certification and are equipped to compete with tablets like the Google Nexus 7 and Amazon Kindle Fire but priced to undercut both. The Hisense Sero 7 Pro is the more compelling of the two devices, featuring specs that belie its budget-friendly $149 price tag. This 7-inch tablet comes equipped with a 1280-by-800-pixel IPS LCD, a quad-core Nvidia Tegra 3 processor, 1GB RAM, and 8GB of internal storage. The Sero 7 Pro will also run Android 4.2 "Jelly Bean." Sound familiar? It should, since that's essentially identical to Google's own Nexus 7 $223.31 at Amazon tablet.

Message.Title: Plan to add
Message.Msg: I don't post often, but I do monitor the boards. I have a standing buy order for tomorrow to add to my position. I've rode the wave from the low 12's and 13's and I'm adding more here to ride the wave into the next two quarters. With rave reviews of T4i, T4 design wins starting to come forward, GRID, and the incredibly impressive Tegra road-map, I'm extremely optimistic about where this company, and in turn, the stock, is headed. Shield begins sales this quarter and while I don't expect blow out numbers, I do expect it to sell moderately well and add some great PR to a company that continues to impress. This company has great leadership, great products, and a great future ahead of it. I'm a super long, so I'm content to watch NVDA grow and continue to put out products that impress the tech community. Dividends and buybacks, a great future, and a stellar balance sheet shows that this company has EVERYTHING going for it. Get in while you can! GL to all longs. XC can go jump off a bridge! JD

Topic.Title: Hisense Tegra 3 Tablet- Sold at Walmart

Message.Msg: $149 is too expensive for a 7 inch tablet. $99 and below is the right price, especially for Wal mart shoppers.

Topic.Title: Hisense Tegra 3 Tablet- Sold at Walmart

Message.Msg: Engadget comments on HiSense's tablets: ""There are a lot of 7-inch tablets on the market, but few can be had at a US-based retailer for less than 100 bucks. Chinese manufacturer Hisense is set to undercut that saturated market with a pair of budget Jelly Bean tablets: the Sero 7 LT, priced at $99, and the Sero 7 Pro with a $149 MSRP. While both devices include similar housings, the internals differ significantly, as you might expect. The cheaper model includes a 1.6GHz dual-core CPU, 1GB of RAM, 4 gigs of internal storage (plus a microSD slot with support for 32GB cards), a 1,024 x 600-pixel 7-inch display, 0.3-megapixel front-facing camera, a four-hour battery and Android 4.1. The Pro model boasts a 1.3GHz quad-core Tegra 3 processor, 1GB RAM, 8 gigs of storage, an upgraded 1,280 x 800 display, a 2MP camera up front with a 5MP cam on the rear, up to 10 hours of battery life and Android 4.2. You should be able to snag both tablets at your local Walmart store or through the retailer's website beginning tomorrow.""

Topic.Title: Hisense Tegra 3 Tablet- Sold at Walmart

Message.Msg: I read that Walmart routinely orders drug tests and character screens for prospective employess. Some of the bashers here may not pass.

Topic.Title: Hisense Tegra 3 Tablet- Sold at Walmart

Message.Msg: Yeah, Walmart shoppers can't afford anything over $100. That's why Apple doesn't bother to sell there. (BTW, Walmart is second only to Best Buy in external sales of Apple products.) It's easy to turn your nose up at Walmart if you have easy access to different retailers. But there are big parts of the U.S. where Walmart is the only reasonable local store. Getting Walmart to sell your product is a big deal. For this product Walmart probably built in a big margin, and can drop the price significantly if they wish. It's probable that they'll use it as leverage to push down their wholesale cost for Apple' products.

Topic.Title: Hisense Tegra 3 Tablet- Sold at Walmart

Message.Msg: That's a fine price for the equipment. You do see $99 tablets, but the specs for those are going to provide a disappointing experience. This kind of spec seems likely to deliver a tablet that customers will actually be happy with.

Topic.Title: JUST IN: Tom's hardware says Tegra 4i is more "future proof" than competition (meaning QC)

Message.Msg: You can't make any money in the market betting on RELEASED products. Go ask apple investors how that's working for them. Betting on future products is how you make the $$$. Products that have the ability to blindside the market and create upside surprise are what you need to get excited about. T4i, GRID are mysteriously awesome at this point based on the current valuation of the stock.

Message.Title: EETimes: "Time to prepare for the ending of Moore's law", says Broadcom CTO
Message.Msg: Rick Merritt 5/23/2013 12:39 AM EDT MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. – The party’s not over yet, but it’s getting time we start thinking about calling a cab. That’s Henry Samueli’s view of the semiconductor industry in a nutshell. The chief technology officer of Broadcom Corp. was shockingly frank in an on-stage interview at an event celebrating the 40th anniversary of Ethernet. “Moore’s Law is coming to an end—in the next decade it will pretty much come to an end so we have 15 years or so,” Samueli told several dozen Silicon Valley technology veterans. “Standard CMOS silicon transistors will stop scaling around 5 nm and everything will plateau,” he said. “I am comfortable we will get to terabit networking speeds, but I’m not sure I see a path to petabit speeds,” said the co-founder of one of the world’s largest communications chip companies. “You will see density of network switch boards leveling off and when you see the network progress level off it will change the dynamics of the entire industry,” he said. “We still have another 15 years or so to enjoy, but we need to prepare at some point for a network that doesn’t double in bandwidth every two years,” he added. Plenty of pundits have predicted the end of CMOS scaling before, but rarely veteran executives of well established chip vendors with deep technical understanding. Before co-founding Broadcom in 1991, Samueli was a professor of electrical engineering at UCLA, specializing in communications chips. The end of CMOS scaling “has been one of my biggest concerns for some time,” Samueli told EE Times after participating in a panel discussion. “We’ve been talking to customers about this for awhile,” he said. SOURCE: EE Times eetimesDOTcom/electronics-news/4415006/Broadcom--Time-to-prepare-for-the-end-of-Moore-s-Law

Topic.Title: JUST IN: Tom's hardware says Tegra 4i is more "future proof" than competition (meaning QC)

Message.Msg: Tegra 4i is nothing but cover for Tegra 4 being a disastrous miss. Nvidia isn't hurting for resources, they can hire another coder with those billions to keep Tegra 4 on schedule if Tegra 4 was on schedule. You could have asked the old Tegra UNIT HEAD all about how well Tegra 4 was going while he was cleaning out his desk, collecting his belongings and handing in his badge if he wasn't in such a hurry to get away. lol He's gone because Tegra 4 is DOA He probably spent his last days there holed up in his office playing with his prototype SHIELD Toy. The Tegra "project" is a mess and QCOM is enjoying Nvidia's Tegra melt down. IMHO
